title: Frank Mellish
text:
Frank Whitmore Mellish, <a href="Military%20Cross">MC</a> (26 April 1897 – 21 August 1965) was a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer who played internationally for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> and <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa</a>. After his rugby career, he served as a selector for the South African team and as the manager of the <a href="1951%E2%80%9352%20South%20Africa%20rugby%20union%20tour">1951 Springbok tour of the British Isles and France</a>.
Mellish was born in <a href="Rondebosch">Rondebosch</a>, Cape Town where he attended <a href="Wynberg%20Boys%27%20High%20School">Wynberg Boys' High School</a>, <a href="Rondebosch%20Boys%27%20High%20School">Rondebosch Boys' High School</a>, and <a href="South%20African%20College%20School">SACS</a>. During World War I, he served in South-West Africa as a gunner with the <a href="Cape%20Town%20Highlanders%20Regiment">Cape Town Highlanders</a> in the South African Heavy Artillery from 1914 to 1915. On 15 May 1915 he sailed on the "SS City of Athens" to Europe where he received the <a href="Military%20Cross">Military Cross</a> for action at <a href="Second%20Battle%20of%20Ypres">Ypres</a> in 1916. He undertook officer training in England, followed by a stint at the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%2C%20Woolwich">Royal Artillery Cadet School</a> before his promotion to 2nd Lieutenant (and later acting Lieutenant). He then served on the <a href="Western%20Front%20%28World%20War%20I%29">Western Front</a> with the South African Heavy Artillery where he was wounded in the left leg in April 1918. He relinquished his commission on 1 June 1919.
After the War he played for <a href="Blackheath%20F.C.">Blackheath</a> and was elected a <a href="Barbarian%20F.C.">Barbarian</a> in the 1919–20 season. His test début for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> came on 17 January 1920, against Wales, playing in the position of Flanker. He represented England on five more occasions, against France, Ireland and Scotland (1920), and Wales and Ireland (1921). He was then chosen to represent South Africa in the <a href="1921%20South%20Africa%20rugby%20union%20tour%20of%20Australia%20and%20New%20Zealand">first Springbok tour of New Zealand</a> in 1921.
Following his rugby career he worked as a business executive with United Tobacco Company Ltd and as a flower farmer. However, on the outbreak of World War II, he served as a colonel in the South African Armoured Division. Following the war he returned to rugby where he represented South Africa on the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20Union">Rugby Football Union</a> from 1945 to 1946. He took over as the convener of the national selectors after <a href="Bill%20Schreiner">Bill Schreiner</a> and as the manager of the <a href="1951%E2%80%9352%20South%20Africa%20rugby%20union%20tour">1951 Springbok tour of the British Isles and France</a>. <a href="Danie%20Craven">Danie Craven</a> rated him the best Springbok manager of all time.
His daughter, Margaret, married <a href="Robinson%20baronets">Major Sir Wilfred Robinson, 3rd Bt.</a> in 1946. Mellish died on 21 August 1965 and his ashes were scattered at <a href="Newlands%20Stadium">Newlands Stadium</a>.
